title: Fareed Aziz: Leads That Show - Discovery Call
meeting_title: Fareed Aziz: Leads That Show - Discovery Call

transcript.text: Fareed, how are you?
Good, how about you, Liam?
Yeah, very well.
Where are you calling from today?
I'm in West Virginia, how about you?
In where, sorry?
West Virginia.
Oh, okay, nice.
Nice.
What's the time for you then?
Let me guess, right?
I'm going to say you're somewhere between, it's not 11, I think you're in the middle, I'm going to say 9 or 10.
Damn.
So as you can probably tell, I'm not from the States, so I never have any idea what time it is for you guys.
I have to kind of guess between the two, Eastern and Western, but it's a little fun game, I like to play at the start of call, breaks the ice a little bit.
So, yeah.
Yeah, look, Fareed, I'm going to dive straight into things with us here.
We've only got 30 minutes, I'm going to make the most of our time.
So I run leads that show we are a B2B outbound agency.
We work with B2B companies, we book them appointments, as simple as that, right?
So I think there's potential.
I there's
for us to work together and for it to be a good fit.
And yeah, I just want to explore that on the call.
What you guys do in a little bit more detail.
I assume it's BPL from looking at the website and doing a little bit of research.
I just want to dive into a little bit around kind of what you're looking to get out of the call.
And then we can dive into the company a little bit more and what you're looking to achieve.
Sure.
Sounds good.
How long have you been in business, Liam?
About a year now.
Okay.
Okay.
So what made you book the call?
I'm sorry?
What made you book the call?
Oh, yeah.
So I was intrigued by, I think, the email that I received that you guarantee about 20 calls that you could book leads that are qualified leads.
So I was interested to learn more.
And I'm actually in a process.
I have been interviewing some marketing firms.
And I was actually making it.
Going to make a decision this week, then yours showed up.
said, okay, let's one last call before I make that determination.
So I thought the timing was right.
And I thought, let me learn more.
And then next week or next week, couple of weeks, we'll make a determination of what route we want to take.
That makes sense.
Okay, cool.
In terms then of how your other interviews have gone interested in, how have they been?
Are they like similar agencies doing a similar thing?
Larger agencies have been in business for longer.
Okay.
Yeah.
Makes sense.
Okay, tell me a little bit about the business because I'll be honest with you.
I've worked with a couple of BPO people in terms of staffing and things like that.
Mixed results, depending on the industry.
The general ones, just to be honest, I get less results for the specialist ones.
I have just taken on a new.
Client that's in the medical space, pretty similar to you guys.
Could even be a competitor, to be honest with you.
So interested to hear around kind of what makes you guys different and your kind of specialty in terms of that staff outsourcing.
Sounds good.
Did you hear that sound?
Or is it just...
No, no, I didn't hear anything.
Perfect.
All right.
I'm getting a call, so...
Okay.
Do you need to take it?
Uh, no, since we have a scheduled time, we'll be on this call and I'll take that later on.
So, yeah, so we are into healthcare staffing, predominantly back-end revenue cycle, basically end-to-end revenue cycle.
So we help our organizations, whether it's a medical group or a large healthcare system, we help them with, you know, onboarding, qualified, experienced staff offshore.
That helps them reduce the costs and also addresses the staffing concerns that we have been...
This Take Okay.
Experiencing in the healthcare industry in the U.S.
We also do end-to-end revenue cycles.
instead of staffing, if someone wants us to manage the whole end-to-end revenue cycle process, we hire our own leadership and we help them with that process.
We do interim leadership.
So if a leader is in transition and they're looking for a leader to temporarily support their operations, we do that.
And we also help clients support with assessments.

So if they're looking to evaluate their revenue cycle processes and evaluate if they are performing well or they have any concerns, we'll identify the opportunities we evaluate and give them actionable items that they could work on that will help them improve their bottom line.
But predominantly, initial, the start of Steward was really focused on staffing because I come from a healthcare revenue cycle background, have over 21 years.
of experience have been executives with at-large healthcare organizations.

One of the challenges that I've noticed with any other window partners that we worked with, there was always multiple layers between the colleague that was actually doing the work and the people who we were communicating.
There was always a communication breakdown.
The quality was a struggle and transparency was out of the window.
So we established Tour Global Consulting back in 22 to address that issue.
And we have been able to address that for large organizations and have started with just two employees back in 23, first client.
Now we are over 75 and we have not spent a penny in marketing.
This was all based upon the value we were able to bring to the clients that allowed us to grow.
So now that we...
You know, we have proven our concept has worked really well.
Our revenues grew significantly.
We are now focused on how do we bring our services to other clients, other hospital systems, academic medical centers.
We're struggling and have the same situation.
So our concept is pretty straightforward.
We don't hire anybody without experience.
We look for at least three plus years of experience.
We allow our clients, we're confident enough to allow our clients to interview those colleagues.
And also those colleagues report directly to the leadership, the client leadership.
So that creates continuous transparency.
Other, whereas the other partners or rep competitors, what their focus is that they hire people of the college, school, which is not bad, but you don't have the experience.
There's a challenge with learning and all that.
Every sector is one industry where you can't go to school and learn.
There's no such thing called, you know, a course that you could take just to learn.
This comes out of experience.
This comes out of really hard learning, which takes a year, a year, two years.
So our concept is pretty similar.
Keep it transparent, keep it simple.
Our cost is very, if I were to compare with any of the competitors, we are very, very low in our cost.
And it's one fixed monthly cost per FTE, which becomes easier for our clients to budget very well because it doesn't fluctuate on our contingency-based model.
And contingency-based model typically are very expensive compared to fixed model.
So the focus is really to drive value and be good stewards of the client's resources and reduce their costs while, you know, improving their quality.
So we have done that very well.
I've been very busy.
As you could imagine, we grew from two to over 70 colleagues.
In two years, we've been very busy in catering to those clients.

Now that we have a good, solid process, and we were able to successfully, another challenge, I think, don't know if you talk to any BPOs, one of the myths that you hear in the industry is that it's a heavy turnover.
So I wanted to evaluate that as well.
Will that be the case if we have good, strong leadership?
So in years' time, we only had one voluntary resignation.
So we really proved our concept and thought process from a colleague perspective, from a client perspective.
So we had a place now, I don't know how much you know about the U.S.
market, the one big, beautiful bill.
You may have heard about that, Trump's tax bill.
It has everything else in it.
It's not just a tax bill.
That impacts the hospital systems significantly with their bottom line.
Already struggling, but that one big, beautiful bill is all, you know, going to even...
and make it worse.
So this is the time the CFOs of the organizations are looking to reduce their cost.
So this is a perfect opportunity where we place Steward in front as a solution to their staffing challenges that are already there.
But now on top of that, I mean, you already have the margin problems.
So we will help them with reducing that cost significantly.
So that's a little bit about Steward Global Consulting and how we started off and happy to answer any specific questions you have.
No, I appreciate it.
It was a good breakdown.
I just want to unpack that a little bit as well then.
So it sounds like you've probably spent the last two years kind of growing the company pretty quickly.
And now you're looking for kind of an outsourced marketing kind of agency, firm help, whatever you want to refer to it as to kind of continue that growth for the next couple of years.
Basically, it's like a long-term partner, really.
And obviously, it's...
Sounds like time is of the essence, if I'm not mistaken, with this kind of bill coming through.

This is a key trigger for these people to potentially reduce headcount and go with someone like yourself where they can kind of reduce that overhead really easily whilst maintaining high qualities of staff.
Would that be fair to say?
Yes, and also sometimes not reducing the overhead.
They already have open positions but not able to fill.
So it's a challenge of willing to pay, don't have the resources or I don't have qualified resources.
So that's a struggle post-pandemic every healthcare leader had to address and has been an issue since then.
No, it makes sense.
And you said, just correct me if wrong, you said one flat fee per head, right?
Is that per role?
Is it banded by tier?
It's here, because you said about leadership roles, interim leadership roles, that sort of thing.
I assume that wouldn't be the same flat fee as.
It's someone who's in like a more junior role.
No, so same concept, but those are onshore colleagues.
These are not offshore colleagues, obviously experienced colleagues.
So it will still be per month cost for the client, but obviously it'll be a lot higher, a lot higher than...
Yeah, yeah, of course, that's what I thought.
No, it makes sense.
Okay, then in terms of what do you guys...
So let's say you...
So what I'm trying to ask is the annual contract value.
I don't know how to kind of frame it in the right way for your business model, because I guess without...
Let's say we got you a deal, they could hire one person, they could hire 10 people.
So it kind of ranges.
But in terms of then the average contract value, just give me a rough number just so I can make sure it makes commercial sense for both of us.
Yeah, we typically don't encourage any contracts that does not hire at least five because that helps us reduce the cost.
But I've broken that rule to accommodate clients, so I'm open to...
So our minimum FTE cost would be around $2,600, $2,700 per month, okay?
That's per FTE.
But that could go much higher.
It could go to $5,000, $7,000, depending upon who we're hiring and what skillset we're looking for.
Because we not only help in revenue cycle, we also do all things healthcare.
So it could be accounts payable.
It could be IT.
If they're looking for IT resources, offshore resources we can offer, obviously those would be a lot much higher value.
But it would be a lot of significant saving if they were to hire someone.
let's go.
let's
Locally or a contracted employee from U.S., it'll be night and day.
Yeah, exactly.
Makes sense.
And I just did some quick math there, and please correct me if I'm wrong.
So if I say $2,600 a month times five, just for five employees on a minimum contract, let's say, I know you've broken the rule before, times 12 gives me $156,000, call it $150,000 a year.
Okay.
What would be your margin on that then?
Because I assume that you've also got to pay for the staff.
So is it about 50%, 40%?
What does that look like?
It's not that high.
And also, it depends.
the $2,600 was the lowest that I would offer, but same position could be $3,000, depending upon who we're talking to, but we don't go lower than $2,600.
Okay.
The margins, again, there's a lot more cost than just the FTE, right?
So in this case, the...
Client is not responsible for any of the hardware we provide.
Right.
Right.
So there's many other costs, the benefits.
We provide benefits to our colleagues.
These are not temporary consultants.
These are full-time employees.
So we have good margins, but I'm not sure if I'm comfortable sharing those level of details here.
No, okay.
What I'm just trying to get at is, for example, how much are going to make off a deal?
Now, I'm going to say, even if it's 10%, right?
You don't need to tell me.
I'm just going to use 10% as an example.
We've taken the lowest cost.
We've taken the lowest margin.
It's still 15K a deal a year, right?
That's what I'm trying to get to.
What I don't want to turn around is you to say, just to weed this out, would be like, oh, if you make 1K for a deal over a year, it's probably not worth us working together, right?
Because it wouldn't work commercial sense for both of us to do that.
So that's fine.
I think that's kind of good enough in terms of the deal size.
I think in terms of your total addressable market as well, that's another thing we look at.
Obviously, healthcare in America is huge.
And I think with this kind of...
he's I'm to Um,
So geopolitical trigger coming through with this big, beautiful bill.
It's a big opportunity that you need to take advantage of now.

And it's going to be great for positioning in terms of how we're going to do that in an email because it's a trigger to get someone to respond that we can use from an external perspective to kind of push them internally to get on a meeting with you guys and explore this option further.
So that's good.
In terms of, and I know you mentioned earlier around you haven't spent a dollar on marketing.
Is that true up until the point of today?
Or was that just for the two years?
Not a dollar until today?
No.
Okay, perfect.
So my question then is, what have you been doing to get clients?
Like referrals?
How does that work?
Yeah, we grew organically because our clients valued what we brought to the table and that's how we got contracts.
And I also had a full-time executive role.
Okay.
I wouldn't say on the side, that was my full-time executive role in my organization and steward global consulting.
I had absolutely no time building business or growing because we were already growing in a pace that I was happy with.
So understanding the challenges in the market and we have a solution, I chose to resign from my executive role last month to focus on just business.
So that's another reason why I felt now that I'm going to invest the time, I need a partner who could really help me scale.
Yeah, makes sense, to be honest with you.
It sounds like you've been a busy guy, Fareed, I'll be honest.
That sounds like a lot on your plate running this as well, 275 employees as well as an executive role.
You've been a very busy man, so hopefully we can get you some time back.
But it's good that you've now got all your time to focus on this.
So that's kind of a positive, right?
I'm just thinking then, so the growth has been good organic.
And now you're trying to kind of add fuel to the fire, let's say, for want of a better word.
Now, you've been relying on kind of the organic growth.
So I assume, and you can tell me here, do you have a growth target in mind for 2026?
Obviously, in January, that's kind of part of the strategic planning for the year.
What does that look like in terms of what you're trying to achieve?
Yeah, so I'll give you an example.
The first year we grew, I think, we started off, I established the company in 22, 23 was the first client we onboarded at the end of the 23.
So my revenues were $170,000 the first year.
The second year in operations, $1.3 million.
Third year in operations, $2.1 million.
So I am looking to double that.
Okay.
Okay, makes sense.
So you're looking for $4.2 million in revenue in...
2.26 forecast.
That's double 2.1 is the number where that's coming from.
And how many deals would that be?
Do you know in terms of clients?
It depends.
Yeah, so it depends on a client.
So there are times when a client, just a single client, would want you because if they're going through an EMR conversion, right, they need resources to augment their staffing.
It could be that they may ask for 10, 15, 20, 30 FTEs that they need resources.
There could be medical groups.
There are large medical groups with 100 providers.
They may need for their end-to-end revenue cycle about 30 FTEs, right?
So it really depends upon who you knock the doors.
Now, if you're talking about independent practice with just one doctor or two providers, in that case, they may not need more than two or three FTEs.
So it really depends who you, you know, target.
And if you get a large organization, they need maybe 50 FTEs.
So it all depends on the price of the client that you're targeting.
Yeah, I'm just doing some quick maths here.
again, please tell me if I'm wrong.
We previously said five employees was about 150k revenue, and that's on the lower end, right?
Bottom.
So I'm just going to use that as the baseline.
So 10 kind of employees would be 300k.
If we're looking to double, we need another 2.1 million.
So if I divide 2.1 million divided by 300k, that's seven clients.
So we call it 14 on the base.
So call it 14 clients you need across the year, right?
That's what I'm forecasting as a rough estimate.
That's about one or two a month, let's call it.
And then in terms of your close rate on that, do you know what that is?
So, so far, as I mentioned, it was all organic growth.
if the client...
it very different.
We were able to, you know, so we didn't really have cases where we got on a call and we didn't have a result.
So with that said, it could be different here.
If someone is interested to get on a call to discuss a decision maker, not anyone in a position that may not be able to make a decision, they're already interested.
They like the idea.
They're interested.
Now we just have to prove and get their confidence that we can make it happen because they already like the idea of the cost savings.
So we need to cater to their needs and be able to quickly make that happen and hopefully also get a client referral that is not, you know, it is possible to make that happen as well.
Provide them a referral so they feel comfortable.
So it all really depends.
I would say in a worst case, let's, let's go with 20% close rate.
with 20%, 20%, let's let's go let's go go Thank
So if you talk to 10, we were able to onboard two, sign a contract.
So in that case, we're talking about, you said, what, 14 clients to be onboarded?
So, yeah.
70 meetings over a year, call it 10 a month, I'd say, roughly.
So if we could deliver 10 meetings a month, think you'd be pretty satisfied with that, right?
And I know I've kind of asked you a lot of questions, so I will, let me go into what we do, because I know we've only got seven minutes here.
We can book a follow-up call if we need to, but I know you're trying to make a decision quickly.
So let me run you through our approach.
I think we could definitely help you.
I'll keep it kind of short and sweet, and then you can ask me questions on it.
I think that's probably the best way to go about this due to the lack of time.
So with our agency, we take a slightly different approach to most people.
We do exercise number one, which is full-time mapping.
So you said to me there around, you only want to speak to the people who can actually make a decision, right?
So you would tell me who they are in terms of the audience?
We'd have a call about it and what that looks like.
So who are the decision makers?
Then I'd go away and map out who are all of them across all of the people you want to speak to in the United States.
OK, so let's say there's 100,000 of them for the sake of the numbers I'm about to say.
Now, with that, you can normally get about 60% of them with email.
OK, that's just like general statistics, email coverage.
The rest you can't find an email for.
They're not on LinkedIn or you just can't get an email.
So we bridge that gap with cold calling and LinkedIn.
Right.
So we give you a full time coverage in terms of contacting every single person in your total adjustable market every 45 to 60 days is our goal.
And I'll focus on email for a second.
So what we're going to do is we're going to not send a seven, eight email sequence like most people.
We're going to send one or two emails that has a relevant message to something that's relevant to right now.
So it could be about the big, beautiful bill, like you mentioned.
So this is coming in.
Is now the right time to kind of explore an option with us?
Then statistics.
There's only 3% of the market ever really looking for a solution.
And what most people will do is they'll look for triggers, for example.

So they'll look for a hiring trigger for a hospital, which is obviously a key intent signal for you guys, because it's like, okay, they're hiring, they could just use us instead and save the money, right?
Or open positions at a medical center, again, another key intent signal.
But that's focusing on the 3% that's ready, rather than focus on 100%.
So our approach is also doing that.
But we're also going to email everyone else, because not everyone's going to be posting about it on social media.

So we're going to use a message that's going to hit the right person at the right time, they're going to raise their hand, they're going to say, yeah, I'm interested in a meeting, we booked that meeting for you, we handle all responses up until the point we're on the phone with you.
And then after 45 days, we're going to go out to that audience again.
Okay, and because we only sent them one or two emails, they're not going to remember it, they probably may have deleted out of their inbox, it wasn't relevant to them at that time.
But in the next 45 days, when it's crisis mode, and they need to...
Reduced costs, and they're having a staffing shortage, and they need a solution.
Now, we pop up, right message, right person, right time.
So that's our approach is a little bit different to most people.
But that's how I think we would get you at least 10 meetings a month, and kind of deliver consistently quarter over quarter.
So it's not, okay, yeah, we get a load of meetings this month, and then, oh, no, then it tails off, tails off, tails off.
Our approach is really simple.
We're going to reach out to all of them every 45 to 60 days, and then try to get them on meetings with you.
And we handled all replies and everything else up until the point they're on that meeting.
So I'll let you ask any questions or anything.
I know I went through that pretty quickly.
Yeah, so I know we have four minutes left, but I could go 10 minutes over.
But let me give you a quick...
Give me two seconds.
Let me check my calendar.
I think I have a call.
Yeah, I do have a call.
But what I can do is I'll monitor my email.
And if that person doesn't join, we can carry on.
How does that sound?
Yeah, that's fine.
So what I'm looking for is a partner, business development partner.
I'm for Thank
Who would guarantee, right?
There has to be some minimum guarantees of what you could bring to the table or work on a commission basis.
So if it's a win-win, if we make money, you make money.
So keep that in mind as you're thinking and discussing and coming up with a proposal that may make more sense.
Because to me, partnership goes a long ways.
I want it to be a long-term relationship since I did not have any marketing.
Neither do I want to grow that internally.
That's not my niche.
I'm more of an operational guy.
So I really need that partner who could really deliver.
So that's something I will obviously keep in mind.
The other piece, we're not after filling the positions for them more so.
But every organization, no matter if they have 600,000 employees doing that work, they still have vendor partners already who are providing the services.
They may not be happy with those services.
So our goal is to approach in a way that we can reduce your vendor costs today Bye.
you.
the quality and reducing your cost.
This is how we work.

Because anytime when you challenge or go after the open positions or positions that they want to fill locally, political challenges come into play and they may not like the idea of losing those jobs, right?
So unless if you're talking to CFO who is looking at a larger scale and they're looking into the overall budget, then that's a different conversation.
But if I'm talking to a VP or a director, it's a totally different concept.
Director may not resonate if you say, hey, instead of filling those positions, go with us.
So there's many different ways we could address this.
Probably in the next meeting, we can talk more about it.
But what I'm really looking for, and I have a couple of partners that I've talked to, potential partners that I've talked to, who are confident to deliver results.
And the contract is going to be based upon win-win scenario.
So it'll be commission-based or contingent-based.
So whatever you want to call it, if we close a deal, they get paid.
There's a minimum that they will charge on a monthly basis, very minimum to cover their costs for marketing.
But other than that, they actually profit when we profit.
So those are the kind of models that I'm interested in.
So if you could please put something together.
I know you have some minimum guarantees.
That's why I thought it's still worth a conversation.
And if you're confident enough.
Yeah, makes sense.
Look, I don't want to cut you off.
I know we've only got one minute here.
But just to be fully transparent and honest with you, if you have got someone lined up, and they are going to do something on a rev share basis, then I would suggest going with them.
It's going to be a very risk free approach for you.
That's not something that's not how we operate, just to be completely honest.
It is the sales process is outside of our control.
So we just don't we can't rely on that as a business, right?
We like to control the variables that are inside our control, which is why we go with the approach.
Which we do.
But I would recommend
And going with the person who is going to do it on a rev share model.
And then if it doesn't work out, you can come back to us and we can kind of revisit this conversation.
And I know you said you were looking to kind of make a conversation before I emailed you.
So maybe go with that one for now.
And then we can revisit this if that doesn't work out.
But that would be my recommendation for now, just to be completely honest with you, because I think that's too good to pass up.
Yeah, so other piece that I probably, maybe the semantics, they guarantee the leads, the qualified leads.
You can't control the sale that's on me, right?
So as long as there's a guarantees of specific, who do we consider a qualified lead is?
If he can be on the same page and the number of leads that you could get each month, where you could schedule those meetings, that's what I'm looking for from a partner.
Yeah, makes sense.
Makes sense.
So yeah, we can continue that conversation.
terms of qualification, just to cover it up, I have got this person's job on my other call.
Two things.
The qualification you would set, so you could say to me, Liam, I know it's expected.
That's part of the onboarding process.
You'll define it and we'll have a call and agree on that.
Not a problem.

In terms of guarantee, and if you're talking about a monthly guarantee, that's not something I'd look to do, just to be honest, because one month, if you said, I want 10 calls a month with qualified leads, I might do eight month one, 12 month two, and 15 month three.
Or pick the number you want.
And then if you say, Liam, you didn't deliver 10 calls in month one, I don't think that's very fair because we delivered it over the quarter.
So if you're looking at a quarterly number, then yeah, potentially we can look at that and what that means for you and kind of how that ROI works out.
That's absolutely fine.
But I am going to have to drop, I'll drop you an email after this call.
And we can continue conversation on email.
If need to jump on another call, we can do that.
But I appreciate your time, Fareed.
I'll speak to you soon.
